channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: Australian universities: A waning soft power
item.description: Driven by political mood rather than long-term strategy, higher education has become fast, fragile and transactional.

item.title: One size does not fit all for social media bans
item.description: With half its population under 18, Nigeria shows why Australia-style digital bans could stifle democratic activism.

item.title: Trump Intensifies Pressure Campaign on Venezuela
item.description: But as the legality of U.S. boat strikes comes into question, the White House’s regime-change ambitions may be curbed.

item.title: Trump Considers Expanding Military Operations to Venezuela
item.description: But as the legality of U.S. boat strikes comes into question, the White House’s regime-change ambitions may be curbed.

item.title: How to spot a bubble bursting
item.description: Forget valuations. Look out for search-engine hits and fund managers getting fired

item.title: Tech’s Tarnished Halo
item.description: How Silicon Valley’s declining image is dimming America’s light.

item.title: Leaf blowers are the latest thing dividing Americans
item.description: An argument that pitches neighbour against neighbour

item.title: American-Led Regime Change Is Usually Disastrous
item.description: The arrogance that led to Iraq now threatens catastrophe in Venezuela.

item.title: Lessons from the frontiers of AI adoption
item.description: Why coders and call-centre agents are especially vulnerable to the technology

item.title: The War Room newsletter: Sleepwalking into Africa’s next war
item.description: Tom Gardner, our Africa correspondent, explores lessons from 20th-century Europe for the Horn of Africa

item.title: Europe is going on a huge military spending spree
item.description: But with America now an unreliable ally, will it be enough to counter Russia?

item.title: Mormonism’s surprising boom in Africa
item.description: The American sect has come a long way from being “the white people’s church”

item.title: Nigeria Needs Safe Schools
item.description: Terrorists are once again targeting Nigeria’s schools, kidnapping more than 300 children in recent weeks. The international community must provide the Nigerian government with immediate surveillance support to secure the release of the abducted students, as well as long-term resources to help make the country’s schools safer.

item.title: Trump’s Tariffs Are Hitting India Hard
item.description: Donald Trump’s punishing tariffs have laid bare the fragility of India’s export model, which depends on a handful of markets and a narrow band of relatively low-value-added products. Only by embracing a new model – which emphasizes diversification, regional cooperation, and value addition – can India build long-term resilience.

item.title: The Future of China’s “Electro-State”
item.description: China has built the machinery of an innovative, low-carbon industrial economy capable of leading the global net-zero transition and the unfolding AI revolution. But whether this model will be sustainable depends on China's ability to overcome several major challenges.

item.title: European pensions are in dire need of reform
item.description: Some countries are much better prepared for ageing than others

item.title: Team Mongolia’s Athletic Prowess Makes a Splash on Netflix
item.description: Mongolia’s performance in the show “Physical: Asia” introduced the country – and its sporting prowess – to a new global audience.

item.title: MAGA’s Death Wish
item.description: The future Donald Trump's supporters want – a pre-feminist white Christian America – cannot be attained, which means his MAGA movement has no constructive program. It can only destroy, because nothing it can build would satisfy it.

item.title: Why xenophobia won't solve South Korea's China problem
item.description: A rise in anti-Chinese sentiment damages Seoul’s image and fails to address the real issues of defence and security.

item.title: Dysfunctional Checks and Balances Are to Blame for Hong Kong’s Devastating Fire – Not Bamboo Scaffolding
item.description: Residents had been complaining about fire safety for over a year. That their concerns were neglected raises serious questions about oversight in Hong Kong.

item.title: The Judge at the End of Europe
item.description: When, in a few years’ time, almost everyone is claiming that they opposed Israel’s war crimes in Gaza, the world will remember Judge Nicolas Guillou of the International Criminal Court fondly. But the world will also remember how Europe’s leaders collaborated with Donald Trump by enforcing baseless US sanctions against Guillou.

item.title: The Judge at the End of Europe
item.description: When, in a few years’ time, almost everyone is claiming that they opposed Israel’s war crimes in Gaza, the world will remember Judge Nicolas Guillou of the International Criminal Court fondly. But the world will also remember how Europe’s leaders collaborated with Donald Trump by enforcing baseless US sanctions against Guillou.

item.title: Americans May Envy China’s Deflation. They Shouldn’t.
item.description: Rising prices are a problem, but steadily falling prices pose an existential threat to the economy.

item.title: Voters Favor Presidential Allies Amid ‘Stifled’ Political Scene in Kyrgyzstan
item.description: A quiet campaign resulted in low turnout for the election of a diminished parliament.

item.title: Xi’s New Language on Taiwan Alters the Diplomatic Starting Point
item.description: To anyone familiar with Beijing’s established discourse on Taiwan, Xi’s remarks to Trump represented a significant departure.

item.title: From Early Jewish Refugees to Afghan Neighbors: Don’t Punish a People for One Man’s Crime
item.description: Following a crime committed by one man, Afghans as a group were recast as an “enemy within.” This pattern is not new.

item.title: China vs. Korea: Who Is Winning the Battery Battle in Hungary?
item.description: What began as a Korean-led success story is now transforming into a live demonstration of how quickly – and how decisively – Chinese firms can reshape high-tech markets.

item.title: South Asia’s Debt Addiction
item.description: Rising debt has sparked a new battle for national sovereignty.

item.title: The Triple-Return Ocean Economy
item.description: In the face of escalating climate, geopolitical, and financial instability, investors are underestimating an asset offering outsize environmental, social, and financial returns. But taking advantage of the opportunities provided by the blue economy requires building the foundational architecture for ocean finance.

item.title: The Triple-Return Ocean Economy
item.description: In the face of escalating climate, geopolitical, and financial instability, investors are underestimating an asset offering outsize environmental, social, and financial returns. But taking advantage of the opportunities provided by the blue economy requires building the foundational architecture for ocean finance.

item.title: The Uncomfortable Truth About Climate AI
item.description: Military technologies used to address climate threats are often the same ones used for more nefarious purposes.

item.title: The US in brief: Donald Trump says he has picked next Fed chair
item.description: Our daily political update, featuring the stories that matter

item.title: The End of Ending AIDS
item.description: As the Trump administration pledges to meet global health targets, it has terminated some of its best tools for doing so.

item.title: The New German War Machine
item.description: After World War II, Germany embraced pacifism as a form of atonement. Now the country is arming itself again.

item.title: Israel Is Wondering if America Is Still on Its Side
item.description: Shifts in U.S. policy and public support have Israelis searching for answers.

item.title: Human Rights Violations Persist Under Bangladesh’s Interim Government
item.description: The regime change has not resulted in weakening the rampant abuse of human rights by state institutions.

item.title: Assem Mayar on the Taliban Regime’s Damming of Transboundary Rivers
item.description: “Pakistan’s opposition to dam building on the Kunar River and its tributaries is due to political rather than technical reasons.”

item.title: Tejas Crash in Dubai Raises Questions of Fighter Jet’s Reliability
item.description: Questions are being raised whether the Tejas light combat aircraft, like the MiG-21 before it, is an unreliable “flying coffin” or widow maker.”

item.title: Is Cambodia’s Scam Industry Too Big to Fail?
item.description: New sanctions on the world’s wealthiest criminal could threaten the Hun dynasty.

item.title: Are Palestinians Ready to Shed Hamas?
item.description: How other factions might gain ground.

item.title: ICC Slaps Down Appeal Seeking Former Philippine President’s Release
item.description: Lawyers tried to argue that Rodrigo Duterte's illness and advanced age created “compelling humanitarian grounds” for his interim release to a third country.
